TemplateCategory.Name: 1-key
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates are composed of a single key. If any of these templates conflict with single letter variables that you use frequently, you can move them individually to a disabled folder, or you can disable all templates in this category by clicking the green check box to the left of the "1-key" category node.

TemplateCategory.Name: Assignment Statements
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates create assignment statements.

TemplateCategory.Name: Full
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates build both sides of an assignment statement (e.g., "aa = bb;"). All of these templates have the "=" sign in the middle.

TemplateCategory.Name: Left side only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates build the left side of an assignment statement (e.g., "aa =").

Template.Comment: Text =

TemplateCategory.Name: Right side only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates build the right side of an assignment statement (e.g., "= bb;"). Most of these templates start with "="; a subset of these templates start with "!=".

TemplateCategory.Name: CodeRush 1.1.46 Compatibility
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates are to provide backwards-compatibility with customers upgrading from CodeRush 1.1.46 and earlier versions.

TemplateCategory.Name: Fields
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare fields, parameters, and local variables. These templates all start with an "f". These templates are here primarily for backwards compatibility for customers using CodeRush 1.1.46 or earlier, where the verb for creating fields, parameters, and locals was "f". In CodeRush 1.1.47 and up, this verb was changed to "v" for discoverability reasons.

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring variables of generic types. These templates start with an "f", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
fl. fs. fq. fd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonics for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
fl.i fq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
fd.i,b

Template.Name: f?Generic1Type?.
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Letters following the "." specify the generic parameter type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: f?Generic1Type?.?Type?
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Letters following the "." specify the generic parameter type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: f?Generic2Type?.
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Letters following the "." specify the generic parameter type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: f?Generic2Type?.?Type1?,?Type2?
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified two-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Comma-separated letters following the "." specify the generic parameter types. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: f?Type?0
Template.Comment: Declares a nullable field of the specified type. The letters following the "f" indicate the type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

TemplateCategory.Name: Read-only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare read-only properties. Templates in this category start with the letter "rp" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring read-only properties of a generic type. These templates start with "rp", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
rpl. rps. rpq. rpd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
rpl.i rpq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
rpd.i,b

Template.Name: rp?Generic1Type?.
Template.Comment: Declares a property of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "p" specify the generic. This template allows you to specify the generic parameter type after expansion. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new generic types.

TemplateCategory.Name: Write-only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare write-only properties. Templates in this category start with the letters "wp" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of write-only property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a write-only property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:

Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
wpd.i,b

TemplateCategory.Name: Read/Write
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare properties. Templates in this category start with the letter "p" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring read/write properties of a generic type. These templates start with "p", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
pl. ps. pq. pd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
pl.i pq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
pd.i,b

TemplateCategory.Name: Variables
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates for creating variables. These templates all start with a "v" and are followed by a mnemonic to represent the type.

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring variables of generic types. These templates start with a "v", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
vl. vs. vq. vd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonics for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
vl.i vq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
vd.i,b

Template.Name: #GenericVarNoArgsSpecified#
Template.Comment: Declares a variable inside a class or struct, inside an argument list (a parameter), or inside a code block.

Template.Name: v?Generic1Type?.
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Letters following the "." specify the generic parameter type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: v?Generic1Type?.?Type?
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Letters following the "." specify the generic parameter type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: v?Generic2Type?.
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Letters following the "." specify the generic parameter type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: v?Generic2Type?.?Type1?,?Type2?
Template.Comment: Declares a field of the specified two-parameter generic type. Letters following the "f" specify the generic. Comma-separated letters following the "." specify the generic parameter types. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

Template.Name: v?Type?0
Template.Comment: Declares a nullable field of the specified type. The letters following the "f" indicate the type. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new types.

TemplateCategory.Name: DevEx
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates for Developer Express Products

TemplateCategory.Name: CodeRush
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category make it easier to write CodeRush plug-ins.

TemplateCategory.Name: Directives
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category declare conditional directives.

TemplateCategory.Name: Expressions
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates for checking the value of an identifier on the clipboard. Templates in this category that start with the letter "n" imply a negative boolean operation (e.g., nv = Not Visible). You can also use templates in the Setting Values category inside expressions.

Template.Name: akd
Template.Comment: Alt Key Down

Template.Name: ckd
Template.Comment: Control Key Down

Template.Name: n"
Template.Comment: not equal to a string

Template.Name: n0
Template.Comment: not zero

Template.Name: n1
Template.Comment: not one

Template.Name: na
Template.Comment: not null

Template.Name: nc
Template.Comment: not checked

Template.Name: ne
Template.Comment: not enabled

Template.Name: nn
Template.Comment: not null

Template.Name: nse
Template.Comment: not String.Empty

Template.Name: nv
Template.Comment: not visible

Template.Name: skd
Template.Comment: Shift Key Down

TemplateCategory.Name: GDI
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates for GDI+ development.

Template.Name: rcmd
Template.Comment: Routed Command

Template.Name: rev
Template.Comment: RoutedEvent

Template.Name: tc
Template.Comment: DependencyProperty with coerce value and value changed handlers

TemplateCategory.Name: Identity
TemplateCategory.Comments: The Identify templates all begin with the letter "I" and work with an identifier on the clipboard, pasting it plus a property or method call at the cursor.

TemplateCategory.Name: Member Access
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category access common properties and methods.

Template.Name: cw
Template.Comment: Console WriteLine...

Template.Name: cwf
Template.Comment: Console WriteLine with String.Format(...)

Template.Name: cwq
Template.Comment: Console WriteLine (with quotes)...

Template.Name: ddb
Template.Comment: Debug WriteLine...

Template.Name: wl
Template.Comment: Debug WriteLine

Template.Name: wlf
Template.Comment: Debug WriteLine with String.Format(...)

Template.Name: wlq
Template.Comment: Debug WriteLine (with quotes)

TemplateCategory.Name: Empty
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category access the .Empty static property of many classes and all end with ".e". The letters before the "." represent the struct.

Template.Name: mbq
Template.Comment: Message box with quotes

TemplateCategory.Name: Serialization
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate code to make easier to write serialization code. The "is" template generates the needed methods to implement ISerializable, and the "av" (AddValue) and "gv" (GetValue) templates are used to move data between the stream and a field identifier on the clipboard.

Template.Name: is
Template.Comment: Implements ISerializable

TemplateCategory.Name: Program Blocks
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate program blocks that can be used inside methods and property accessors.

TemplateCategory.Name: Else blocks
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate Else blocks. Nearly all of these templates start with the letter "L". Many of these templates string together powerful combos. For example, "sn" sets the identifier on the clipboard to null. "lsn" creates the "else" keyword, and then sets the identifier on the clipboard to null.

Template.Name: blb
Template.Comment: block - else - block (useful after an if-expression)

TemplateCategory.Name: Flow
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate code that controls program flow. This includes loops (while, for, foreach, etc.), switch statements, and flow breakage (e.g., throw exceptions, return, break, continue, etc.).

Template.Name: #CaseStatement#
Template.Comment: Generates a Case block -- called from the switch template.

Template.Name: #ForLoopRouter#
Template.Comment: Expands the MainForLoop template with the correct upperBound, based on context.

Template.Name: #IteratorVar#
Template.Comment: A linked iterator variable of the for-loop.

Template.Name: #MainForLoop#
Template.Comment: System template that expans to a for-loop. The iteratorVar and upperBound variables should be set before calling.

Template.Name: bk
Template.Comment: C# code block

Template.Name: bk,
Template.Comment: C# code block

Template.Name: do
Template.Comment: do - while loop

Template.Name: dw
Template.Comment: do - while loop

Template.Name: fr?IteratorVar?
Template.Comment: For loop. The mnemonic following the "fr" indicates the iterator variable to use in the loop (try i, j, k, ix, and c).

TemplateCategory.Name: If blocks
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate if blocks. Most start with "if", however a few start with "in", which will lead to "if (!...)" blocks.

Template.Name: cod
Template.Comment: Create on demand

Template.Name: ifa
Template.Comment: if assigned

Template.Name: ifb
Template.Comment: if block

Template.Name: ifn
Template.Comment: if not

Template.Name: ifna
Template.Comment: if not assigned

Template.Name: inr
Template.Comment: if not assigned (or if false) then return

Template.Name: inr"
Template.Comment: if not assigned then return an empty string

Template.Name: inr0
Template.Comment: if not assigned then return zero

Template.Name: inrf
Template.Comment: if not assigned then return false

Template.Name: inrn
Template.Comment: if not assigned then return null

Template.Name: inrt
Template.Comment: if not assigned then return true

Template.Name: inx
Template.Comment: if not assigned then exit (return)

TemplateCategory.Name: Returning Values
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category return values. These templates all start with the letter "r", and end with one or two characters that describe the value to return. For example, "rf" returns false.

Template.Name: ri
Template.Comment: Return Instance -- creates a local variable (called "lResult") of the same type as the method.

TemplateCategory.Name: try...
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate try/finally and try/catch blocks. These templates all start with the letter "t".

Template.Name: tcf
Template.Comment: try/catch/finally

Template.Name: tfb
Template.Comment: Try/Finally block toggles boolean on the clipboard.

TemplateCategory.Name: Regions
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate common regions. Nearly all of these templates start with "re", and are followed by a few letters that describe the region to create. This category also includes "er", a template that generates an #EndRegion directive. Note: CodeRush includes an AutoRegion command (by default bound to Ctrl+3), that will create a region around the current property, method, or event.

Template.Name: repbf
Template.Comment: region - public fields

TemplateCategory.Name: Setting Values
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category all begin with the letter "S" and work with an identifier copied to the clipboard

Template.Name: sbt
Template.Comment: Set Boolean Toggle (toggles the state of the boolean identifier on the clipboard)

Template.Name: sn"
Template.Comment: Need to clear the InString context

TemplateCategory.Name: System
TemplateCategory.Comments: This category contains system templates that are referenced by other templates. Changing these will impact all templates with aliases to them.

TemplateCategory.Name: Declaration Bodies
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category support the declaration of properties, methods, fields, local variables, and parameters.

Template.Name: #NullableTypePrep#
Template.Comment: Adds the nullable modifier to a type declaration is IsNullable == true (otherwise no change)

/* This template tests StringProviders.... Time: Date: «?Date» DateLong: «?DateLong» Year: «?Year» Month: «?Month» Day: «?Day» DayOfWeek: «?DayOfWeek» Hour: «?Hour» Minute(0): «?Minute(0)» Second(0): «?Second(0)» Minute: «?Minute» Second: «?Second» Time: «?Time» TimeLong: «?TimeLong»
File: FileBase: «?FileBase» FileName: «?FileName» FilePath: «?FilePath» FileDrive: «?FileDrive» ProjectName: «?ProjectName» ProjectFileName: «?ProjectFileName» SolutionFileName: «?SolutionFileName»
String Manipulation: InitialCap(testString) = «?InitialCap(testString)» InitialLow(TestString) = «?InitialLow(TestString)»
System Information: UserName: «?UserName» */

Template.Name: ac
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection contains a given object.

Template.Name: acc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection contains a given object, using a comparer.

Template.Name: adnc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection does not contain a given object.

Template.Name: adncc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection does not contain a given object, using a comparer.

Template.Name: adntr
Template.Comment: Verifies that a block of code does not throw any exceptions.

Template.Name: ae
Template.Comment: Verifies that two objects are equal, using a default comparer.

Template.Name: aec
Template.Comment: Verifies that two objects are equal, using a custom comparer.

Template.Name: aem
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection is empty.

Template.Name: af
Template.Comment: Verifies that the condition is false.

Template.Name: aiaf
Template.Comment: Verifies that an object is of the given type or a derived type.

Template.Name: aint
Template.Comment: Verifies that an object is not exactly the given type.

Template.Name: air
Template.Comment: Verifies that a value is within a given range.

Expansion.Body: Assert.InRange(«Caret»«Field(actual,The actual value to be evalua)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(low,The (inclusive) low value of the range)», «Field(high,The (inclusive) high value of the range)»);«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: airc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a value is within a given range, using a comparer.

Expansion.Body: Assert.InRange(«Caret»«Field(actual,The actual value to be evalua)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(low,The (inclusive) low value of the range)», «Field(high,The (inclusive) high value of the range)», «Field(comparer,The comparer used to evaluate the value's range)»);«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: ait
Template.Comment: Verifies that an object is exactly the given type (and not a derived type).

Template.Name: an
Template.Comment: Verifies that an object reference is null.

Template.Name: anc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection does not contain a given object.

Template.Name: ancc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection does not contain a given object, using a comparer.

Template.Name: ane
Template.Comment: Verifies that two objects are not equal, using a default comparer.

Template.Name: anec
Template.Comment: Verifies that two objects are not equal, using a custom comparer.

Template.Name: anem
Template.Comment: Verifies that a collection is not empty.

Template.Name: anir
Template.Comment: Verifies that a value is not within a given range, using the default comparer.

Expansion.Body: Assert.NotInRange(«Caret»«Field(actual,The actual value to be evalua)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(low,The (inclusive) low value of the range)», «Field(high,The (inclusive) high value of the range)»);«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: anirc
Template.Comment: Verifies that a value is not within a given range, using a comparer.

Expansion.Body: Assert.NotInRange(«Caret»«Field(actual,The actual value to be evalua)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(low,The (inclusive) low value of the range)», «Field(high,The (inclusive) high value of the range)», «Field(comparer,The comparer used to evaluate the value's range)»);«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: ann
Template.Comment: Verifies that an object reference is not null.

Template.Name: ans
Template.Comment: Verifies that two objects are not the same instance.

Template.Name: at
Template.Comment: Verifies that an expression is true.

Template.Name: atr
Template.Comment: Verifies that the exact exception is thrown (and not a derived exception type).

Template.Name: [ai
Template.Comment: Apply this attribute to your test method to replace the CurrentPrincipal with another role.

Template.Name: [ar
Template.Comment: Apply this attribute to your test method to automatically create a TransactionScope that is rolled back when the test is finished.

Template.Name: [cd
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming from a class which must implement IEnumerable<object[]>.

Template.Name: [ed
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming a Microsoft Excel (.xls) spreadsheet.

Expansion.Body: [ExcelData(«Caret»«Field(FileName,The filename of the XLS spreadsheet file.)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(SelectStatement,The SELECT statement that returns the data for the theory)»)]«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: [f
Template.Comment: Attribute that is applied to a method to indicate that it is a fact that should be run by the test runner. It can also be extended to support a customized definition of a test method.

Template.Name: [fc
Template.Comment: Apply this attribute to your test method to freeze the time represented by the Clock class.

Expansion.Body: [FreezeClock(«Caret»«Field(year,The frozen year)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(month,The frozen month)», «Field(day,The frozen day)»)]«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: [id
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming from inline values.

Expansion.Body: [InlineData(«Caret»«Field(DataValues,The data values to pass to the theory)»«BlockAnchor»)]«FinalTarget»
[OleDbData(«Caret»«Field(connectionString,The OLEDB connection string to the data)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(selectStatement,The SELECT statement used to return the data for the theory)»)]«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: [pd
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming from a public static property on the test class. The property must return IEnumerable<object[]> with the test data.

Expansion.Body: [PropertyData(«Caret»«Field(PropertyName,The name of the public static property on the test class that will provide the test data)»«BlockAnchor»)]«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: [rw
Template.Comment: Attributes used to decorate a test fixture that is run with an alternate test runner. The test runner must implement the ITestClassCommand interface.

Template.Name: [ssd
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming a Microsoft SQL Server.

Expansion.Body: [SqlServerData(«Caret»«Field(serverName,The server name of the Microsoft SQL Server)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(databaseName,The database name)», «Field(selectStatement,The SQL SELECT statement to return the data for the data theory)»)]«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: [t
Template.Comment: Attribute used to decorate a test method with arbitrary name/value pairs ("traits").

Template.Name: [th
Template.Comment: Marks a test method as being a data theory. Data theories are tests which are fed various bits of data from a data source, mapping to parameters on the test method. If the data source contains multiple rows, then the test method is executed multiple times (once with each data row).

Template.Name: [tr
Template.Comment: Apply to a test method to trace the method begin and end.

TemplateCategory.Name: Text
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category make it easier to work with strings and characters.

TemplateCategory.Name: Transitional
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category provide transitional assistance for developers working in C# that are familiar with other programming languages.

TemplateCategory.Name: Deprecated CodeRush/Delphi
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category are no longer in use in CodeRush for Visual Studio, but are included for CodeRush for Delphi users who depend on them. These templates may conflict with newer, better ways of doing the same thing, so we recommend that this category remain disabled.

Template.Comment: Begin/End block (deprecated for CR/VS -- use "b" instead)

Template.Comment: Delphi-compatibility template - use lb instead.

TemplateCategory.Name: From Visual Basic
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category are for developers familiar with Visual Basic.

TemplateCategory.Name: Types
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate common types. These templates are all abbreviations for the longer type name ("sg" = "string", "dt" = "DateTime", etc.).

TemplateCategory.Name: Using
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate namespace reference declarations. Templates in this category all start with the letter "u" (the equivalent templates start with the letter "i" in VB). To add a namespace, just enter a "u" followed by the uppercase letters of the namespace. For example, to add a reference to "System.Xml", use "usx".

Template.Comment: Class that descends from ClientBase to implement a Service Proxy

Template.Name: nsh
Template.Comment: new WCF ServiceHost instance in a using block, with call to Open();
